awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Constraining West Antarctic Ice Sheet Elevation during the last Interglacial
awd_abstract_narration:
This study will collect a novel dataset to determine how the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) responded to a warmer climate during the last interglacial period (~125,000 years ago) by reconstructing the glacial history at the Mt. Waesche volcano. Reconstructing WAIS geometry when the ice sheet was smaller than present is difficult and data are lacking because the evidence lies beneath the present ice sheet. This study will drill through the ice sheet and recover bedrock that can be analyzed for its surface exposure history to help determine when the surface became overridden by the ice sheet. This study will provide constraints on the past maximum and minimum spatial extent of WAIS during the last glacial-interglacial cycle. Understanding the geometry of a reduced WAIS during intervals when the planet was warmer than present may provide a possible analogue for future environmental conditions given predicted temperature trends. A reduction of WAIS results in rising sea levels which threatens coastal communities across the globe. The data will help improve numerical ice sheet models to better predict WAIS response to current and future climate trends. The project supports a teacher educational workshop and the training of graduate and undergraduate students.

The goal of this project is to obtain rock samples from beneath the WAIS through shallow (<80 m) drilling at Mt. Waesche, a volcano in Marie Byrd Land, near an ice dome of WAIS (2000 m elevation). The lithologies of lava flows exposed on the flank of the volcano are well-suited for cosmogenic 3He and 36Cl as well as 40Ar/39Ar measurements which will establish eruption and exposure age. Existing 40Ar/39Ar data indicate basaltic lava flows on the volcano flank as young as 350 ka. Thus, measured cosmogenic nuclides measured in rock cores from beneath the ice surface will be indicative of relatively recent exposure during periods of reduced ice elevation, most likely, during the last interglacial. The first field season is focused on identifying appropriate locations for drilling and a ground penetrating radar (GPR) survey of the subglacial topography <100m under the blue ice area. Mapping and dating the adjacent exposed lava flows will allow tracing of lava flows of known age and composition below the ice margin that will be targeted for drilling the following year. The second field season activities include drilling 8 boreholes (two transects) through blue ice with the Winkie drill near the ice margin to 80 m depth to obtain rock cores from the sub-ice lava flows. 3He exposure ages will constrain the duration and minimum extent of past surface lowering of the WAIS in Marie Byrd Land. Deeper GPR imaging (up to 700 m) will hope to reveal additional evidence of lava/ice interactions that would independently place constraints on lower ice levels during past eruptions. Results from this study will be compared with the modeled ice elevation histories at Mt. Waesche to validate ice sheet modeling efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project is to constrain West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) thickness during the last interglacial, about 125,000 years ago. Global sea levels were ~5 m higher then, raising concerns that similar levels could be reached in the future, which would be devastating to coastal communities and cities. Data constraining past ice sheet volume changes are key to understanding the response of WAIS to warming climate and potential rates of sea level rise. Nunataks, mountains that project through the ice sheet, act as dipsticks that gauge past changes in ice sheet thickness. Glacial moraines and erratics record higher ice levels.  Lava flows that contact the ice margin or erupt through the ice leave characteristic deposits that also constrain past positions of the ice margin. Lava flows that show no evidence of interaction with ice indicate that ice elevations were lower than the flow when it was erupted. Similar markers of past ice margins that record lower-than-present ice levels presumably occur on nunatak flanks now buried by the WAIS. Cosmogenic isotopes buildup over time in rocks due to interactions with cosmic rays. Critically, this process is limited to the near surface as the cosmic ray flux is attenuated by rock and ice. The presence of cosmogenic isotopes in subglacial bedrock indicate that the rocks were exposed to cosmic rays in the past and thus document lower ice levels. The goal of this project is to obtain subglacial rock samples to test for cosmogenic nuclides

Mt. Waesche, is a volcano near a dome of the WAIS in Marie Byrd land. Previous dating indicated that some lava flows are as young as 300 ka; any exposure of the now ice-covered parts of the flows is necessarily younger than that. Many of the flows have the mineralogy and composition required for cosmogenic exposure dating.  Thus, the geology there provides a unique opportunity to constrain ice thickness during the last interglacial period. We used ice-penetrating radar to map the subglacial bedrock topography to identify sites where lava flows with suitable lithologies identified on the volcano are accessible by the Winkie drill rig. Subglacial samples for cosmogenic analyses will be obtained during the 2024-2025 field season. 40Ar/39Ar dating of lavas on exposed lower flanks of Mt. Waesche collected during the first field season (2018-2019) has identified lava flows emplaced during the last interglacial period that continue beneath the ice margin providing independent constraints on past ice elevation and targets for drilling. 40Ar/39Ar ages of the drilled samples of lava flows will provide a maximum age of the flow and indicate times when ice levels were lower than the drill site.

Although the Harvard University component of this collaborative research project is complete, this research project is on-going. The 2nd field season, that focuses on obtaining subglacial bedrock samples using the Winkie Drill, originally scheduled for year 3 of this project (2020-2021) was delayed due to the Covid-19 pandemic, and subsequent logistical difficulties. This report details the work done at Harvard University that is now complete.

We modeled the time-variant changes in Antarctic bedrock elevation in response to changing ice loads (glacial isostatic adjustment). While our original proposal included this work specifically for Mt. Waesche, we expanded the scope to include the entire Antarctic continent. Subglacial bedrock elevation changes over the last 150,000 years were simulated in 1000-year time steps. The modeled bedrock elevation history allows us to calculate the actual elevation of our anticipated subglacial samples when they were exposed to cosmic rays which is necessary to calculate the duration of exposure, and to place more accurate limits on WAIS thickness at that time. It is also useful for determining the past elevation of moraines and bedrock on Mt. Waesche, and elsewhere in Antarctica that are now above the present-day ice elevation. These features are used to reconstruct past Antarctic Ice Sheet geometry, but their present elevations are higher than when they were deposited due to glacial isostatic adjustment.

An unanticipated finding was that these changes potentially resulted in changes in the subglacial drainage network that impacted ice sheet dynamics. We present predictions of the evolution of bedrock elevation using several published GIA models characterized by excess ice volumes at the last glacial maximum (LGM) ranging from 6-15 meters of sea level change, then use these results to explore the evolution of subglacial water routes from LGM to present day (Figures 1-3).  We find changes in predicted bedrock topography of up to ~400 meters and conclude that water routing during the last deglacial phase likely differed significantly from patterns inferred at present day. The impact of GIA on subglacial flow paths is thus non-negligible and should be accounted for in reconstructions of ancient subglacial hydrology.

Pan et al., Geophys. Res. Lett., submitted, 2024.
